author: piero
post: Well… Apparently, until now, it has not been found the DNA of the American Indians or the DNA of Aboriginal Australians …. However (putting aside the jokes) a scientific study should take into account what we can say with the Calculus of Probability. Then there is another thing to consider: there is not yet a careful comparison with the DNA found on another famous relic: the Sudarium of Oviedo. — — However, as I have already had occasion to emphasize in a previous message, a “marginal difference of DNA” (ie: not for the DNA of the Person who was in contact with the ancient lignocellulosic materials) does not imply anything about the authenticity of the two relics! And, before to finish with the “complex topic DNA”, I still have doubts about the possibility to assign a “rough date” (even with an approximate dating) for the DNA of the people involved in the release of “genetic traces” and extraneous to that dead Man. This “dating of DNA” would help us to solve the problem regarding the contamination with foreign DNA, that is: whether it is a kind of ancient or modern contamination….
title: Numerous Plant Species and Human Lineages Identified. Now What?

author: piero
post: Do you know what is the Society for Organic Petrology (=TSOP)? If I well remember Rogers did indicate to me (only vaguely) something (articles of possible interest regarding the study of the possible age of pollen grains…) about TSOP, twelve years ago (in 2003)… The exact subject was the following: an agreement of TSOP with Elsevier about an offer (at special price) for “the Review of Paleobotany and Palynology” (Elsevier). Links: http://www.tsop.org/ http://www.journals.elsevier.com/review of palaeobotany and palynology.
title: Doubting the Pollen Evidence
